Le conté mi historia y él me escuchó con interés, asintiendo con la cabeza de vez en cuando. Cuando terminé, me dijo que se llamaba Tom y que había trabajado en aquella cuadra durante varios años. La conversación fue agradable y me sentí como si hubiera encontrado un amigo en aquel lugar desconocido. Después de un rato, Tom me preguntó si quería ver el jardín, ya que era un lugar muy bonito. Al entrar, me sorprendió la belleza del lugar, con sus flores y árboles perfectamente cuidados. Mientras paseábamos, noté que había un estanque en el centro del jardín, con varios patos nadando en él. Tom me dijo que el estanque era un lugar favorito de los niños del pueblo, que venían a alimentar a los patos los domingos. en_results_raw: he was urged on by my driver, who had jumped down and was holding the door open for me. I sprang in, and we were off in an instant, rattling and bumping over the stones. I looked back, and saw the cab in which the woman had been driving standing still in the middle of the road, while its occupant gazed after us with a look of nonplussed astonishment. Then the houses seemed to whizz past in a wild dance, and I found myself in Baker Street, with the door of our lodgings open to receive me. I rushed in, and found Holmes sitting in his arm-chair, with his eyes fixed intently upon me. "Well, Watson?" he asked, as I entered. "What news?" I explained the whole affair to him, from the moment that I had seen the woman in the street to my return in the cab. He listened with a curious expression, and when I had finished, he said, "I think, Watson, that we have a most interesting case before us. Pray, what was the number of the cab in which the woman drove?" I told him, and he made a note of it in his book. "And what was the number of the cab in which you drove?" he asked. I told him that also, and again he made a note. "Now, Watson," he said, "I think we have all the data we require. Let us see what we can make of it." And with that, he began to pace up and down the room, his eyes fixed upon the floor, and his hands clasped behind his back.

It was all over in a matter of minutes, and yet, as I watched them turn to leave the church, I couldn't shake the feeling that I had just witnessed something much more significant than a simple wedding.

The cab turned a corner, and we found ourselves in front of a large and handsome house, which stood in its own grounds and was surrounded by a high wall. "I have been expecting this, Watson, and I have been preparing for it. But I must admit, the details are not yet clear to me. We must go over the facts, every one of them, and see if we can uncover the thread that will lead us to the solution." He sat down again, his eyes never leaving mine, and began to drum his fingers on the arm of his chair. "Let us start at the beginning, Watson. Tell me everything you know about this case, every detail, no matter how small it may seem."

After a time, Holmes opened his eyes, and, leaning forward, he gazed intently at the man before him. "I think I see," he said, after a moment's pause. "You have been in a position of trust, and you have been robbed. The thief is someone you trusted, and you are utterly at a loss to know who it could be." The man looked up, and his eyes widened in amazement. "How did you know?" he asked, his voice shaking with emotion. Holmes smiled, and leaned back in his chair. "It is quite simple," he said. "Your attitude, your manner, all point to the fact that you have been robbed by someone you trusted. And, if I am not mistaken, the robbery is not the only thing that is troubling you. There is something else, something that is causing you even greater distress." The man nodded, and Holmes could see the tears welling up in his eyes. "Yes," he said, his voice barely above a whisper. en_results_raw: The flickering flames seemed to be exercising a hypnotic influence over him, and I could see by the steady gleam in his eyes that he was deeply absorbed in thought. Suddenly, he sprang to his feet and began pacing rapidly up and down the room, his long fingers clasped behind his back. I watched him in silence, knowing that it was useless to try to distract him when he was in one of these moods. The clock on the mantlepiece struck the hour, and still he paced, his eyes fixed upon the floor. I could see that he was working out some problem in his mind, and I waited patiently for him to reveal his thoughts. At last, he stopped in front of me and turned, his eyes gleaming with excitement. "I have it, Watson!" he exclaimed. "I have the solution to the mystery!"

Openshaw tiếp tục đọc. "Chúng tôi đã tìm thấy một chiếc dao găm gần thi thể, và một mảnh giấy với một thông điệp kỳ lạ. Thông điệp này nói rằng 'Justice will be served' - Công lý sẽ được thực thi." Giáo sư Moriarty nhíu mày, như thể đang suy nghĩ. "Justice will be served... Đây là một thông điệp rất kỳ lạ. Nó gợi ý rằng vụ giết người này có liên quan đến một sự trả thù nào đó." Openshaw gật đầu. "Đúng, thưa giáo sư. Và chúng tôi đang cố gắng tìm hiểu thêm về quá khứ của nạn nhân để xem có liên quan gì đến vụ giết người này không." Giáo sư Moriarty đứng dậy, bắt đầu đi lại trong phòng. "Tốt, tốt. Hãy tiếp tục điều tra và tìm hiểu thêm về vụ việc này. Tôi sẽ giúp anh tìm ra manh mối và giải quyết vụ này."

en_results_raw: and it was in one of these that I slept on the night of the 5th of March. I had been warned not to go to bed until my father came home, but I was very tired and fell asleep almost as soon as my head touched the pillow. I was awakened by a loud noise, which seemed to come from the room above mine. I sat up in bed and listened, but all was quiet. I then got out of bed and went to the door, which I opened and looked out into the passage. The house was very still, and I could see nothing but the faint glimmer of the night-light which was always left burning in the hall. I was about to go back to bed when I heard a faint cry, which seemed to come from the room above mine. I listened intently, and the cry was repeated. I then knew that something was wrong, and I ran to my father's room, which was at the other end of the passage. I found him sitting in his arm-chair, and he was staring at something on the floor. I looked down and saw that it was a piece of paper, and on it was written a message in red ink. The message was: "They have come." My father looked up at me and said: "It has happened." I did not know what he meant, but I knew that something terrible had occurred. He then told me to go back to bed and try to sleep, but I was too frightened to sleep. I kept thinking of the message on the piece of paper and wondering what it meant. I was also thinking of the cry I had heard, and I was trying to convince myself that it was just my imagination. But I knew that it was not my imagination, and that something was very wrong. I lay in bed for hours, listening to every sound in the house and trying to make sense of what had happened. It was not until the next morning that I found out what had occurred, and it was not until then that I realized the full horror of what had happened.

en_first_half: “Away we went then, and we drove for at least an hour. Colonel Lysander Stark had said that it was only seven miles, but I should think, from the rate that we seemed to go, and from the time that we took, that it must have been nearer twelve. He sat at my side in silence all the time, and I was aware, more than once when I glanced in his direction, that he was looking at me with great intensity. The country roads seem to be not very good in that part of the world, for we lurched and jolted terribly. I tried to look out of the windows to see something of where we were, but they were made of frosted glass, and I could make out nothing save the occasional bright blur
en_second_half: of a passing light. Now and then I hazarded some remark to break the monotony of the journey, but the colonel answered only in monosyllables, and the conversation soon flagged. At last, however, the bumping of the road was exchanged for the crisp smoothness of a gravel-drive, and the carriage came to a stand. Colonel Lysander Stark sprang out, and, as I followed after him, pulled me swiftly into a porch which gaped in front of us. We stepped, as it were, right out of the carriage and into the hall, so that I failed to catch the most fleeting glance of the front of the house. The instant that I had crossed the threshold the door slammed heavily behind us, and I heard faintly the rattle of the wheels as the carriage drove away.

Đại tá Lysander Stark đi đến gần ông ta và bắt tay, sau đó ông ta quay lại và giới thiệu tôi với người đàn ông này. Người đàn ông này có một nụ cười ấm áp và bắt tay tôi. "Xin chào", ông ta nói, "Tôi là giáo sư Everett. Rất vui được gặp bạn". Tôi cảm thấy có chút ngạc nhiên khi nghe ông ta giới thiệu mình là giáo sư, nhưng tôi cũng cảm thấy thoải mái khi được chào đón nồng nhiệt như vậy. Giáo sư Everett dẫn chúng tôi đi đến một phòng khác, trong phòng này có một chiếc bàn lớn với nhiều giấy tờ và tài liệu. Ông ta bắt đầu giải thích về một dự án nghiên cứu mà ông ta đang thực hiện, và tại sao ông ta cần sự giúp đỡ của tôi. Tôi lắng nghe chăm chú và bắt đầu cảm thấy hứng thú với dự án này. Tôi không biết rõ mình sẽ làm gì, nhưng tôi cảm thấy có thể tin tưởng giáo sư Everett và sẵn sàng hợp tác với ông ta.
es_first_half: "Nos fuimos entonces, y condujimos durante al menos una hora. El coronel Lysander Stark había dicho que sólo eran siete millas, pero yo creía, por la velocidad a la que parecíamos ir, y por el tiempo que tardamos, que debían ser más de doce. Se sentó a mi lado en silencio todo el tiempo, y me di cuenta, más de una vez cuando miré en su dirección, que me estaba mirando con gran intensidad. Parece que las carreteras rurales no son muy buenas en esa parte del mundo, porque dimos unos bandazos y sacudidas terribles. Intenté mirar por las ventanillas para ver algo de dónde estábamos, pero eran de vidrio esmerilado, y no pude distinguir nada más que el borrón ocasional de una luz que pasaba. De vez en
es_second_half: cuando me arriesgaba a hacer algún comentario para romper la monotonía del viaje, pero el coronel sólo respondía con monosílabos, y la conversación pronto decaía. Por fin, sin embargo, los golpes de la carretera fueron sustituidos por la crujiente suavidad de un camino de grava, y el carruaje se detuvo. El coronel Lysander Stark se bajó de él y, mientras yo lo seguía, me arrastró a un porche que se abría ante nosotros. Bajamos, por así decirlo, del carruaje y entramos en el vestíbulo, de modo que no pude echar la más fugaz mirada a la fachada de la casa. En el instante en que crucé el umbral, la puerta se cerró de golpe detrás de nosotros, y oí débilmente el traqueteo de las ruedas mientras el carruaje se alejaba."

Salimos del vehículo y nos encontramos en un lugar completamente oscuro, sin luces ni señales de vida en absoluto. El coronel Stark me indicó que lo siguiera y comenzamos a caminar por un sendero estrecho y sinuoso que se adentraba en la oscuridad. No podía ver nada, pero escuchaba el sonido de grillos y el crujido de ramas bajo nuestros pies. De repente, una luz débil apareció en la distancia y el coronel Stark me guió hacia ella. Era una casa pequeña y sencilla, con una puerta de madera y una ventana iluminada. El coronel Stark llamó a la puerta y una voz débil respondió desde el interior. La puerta se abrió y una figura encorvada nos invitó a entrar. Nos encontramos en una habitación pequeña y acogedora, con una chimenea encendida y una mesa con dos sillas. La figura encorvada se presentó como el señor Jenkins y nos ofreció asientos. El coronel Stark se sentó y comenzó a hablar en voz baja, explicando algo que no pude entender. El señor Jenkins asintió con la cabeza y me miró con curiosidad. De repente, el coronel Stark se levantó y me indicó que lo siguiera. Salimos de la casa y nos adentramos en la oscuridad una vez más. No sabía qué estaba sucediendo, pero sentía que estábamos cerca de algo importante. El coronel Stark me guió hacia un claro y allí, en el centro, vi una figura inmóvil. Era un hombre, vestido con un traje negro y con un sombrero en la cabeza. Estaba completamente quieto, sin moverse ni respirar. El coronel Stark se acercó a él y comenzó a hablar en voz baja. La figura no respondió, pero de repente, se movió. Se levantó y se quitó el sombrero, revelando un rostro que me hizo sentir un escalofrío. Era un rostro que había visto antes, pero no podía recordar dónde. El coronel Stark me miró y sonrió. "Este es el hombre que hemos estado buscando", dijo. "Y ahora, es hora de que sepas la verdad".

en_first_half: “It was pitch dark inside the house, and the colonel fumbled about looking for matches and muttering under his breath. Suddenly a door opened at the other end of the passage, and a long, golden bar of light shot out in our direction. It grew broader, and a woman appeared with a lamp in her hand, which she held above her head, pushing her face forward and peering at us. I could see that she was pretty, and from the gloss with which the light shone
en_second_half: upon her dark dress I knew that it was a rich material. She spoke a few words in a foreign tongue in a tone as though asking a question, and when my companion answered in a gruff monosyllable she gave such a start that the lamp nearly fell from her hand. Colonel Stark went up to her, whispered something in her ear, and then, pushing her back into the room from whence she had come, he walked towards me again with the lamp in his hand.
en_results: on her dark hair, I gathered that she was young. Her eyes, which seemed to bore into our very souls, sparkled with curiosity as she took in our disheveled appearance. en_results_raw: on her dark hair, I gathered that she was young. Her eyes, which seemed to bore into our very souls, sparkled with curiosity as she took in our disheveled appearance. The colonel, still muttering to himself, stumbled forward, his eyes fixed on the lamp as if it were a beacon of salvation. As he drew closer, the woman's gaze never wavered, her expression a mixture of fascination and wariness. She was clearly not expecting visitors, especially not at such an ungodly hour. The colonel finally reached her side and, with a courteous bow, relieved her of the lamp, holding it aloft to illuminate our little group. In the warm, golden light, I saw that the woman's features were even more striking than I had initially thought - high cheekbones, a small nose, and full lips that curved downward in a faint, enigmatic smile. As we stood there, frozen in a tableau of awkwardness, I couldn't help but wonder what had brought us to this strange, isolated place, and what secrets the woman and her lamp might hold. The colonel, seemingly oblivious to the tension, began to speak, his voice low and soothing, as if trying to calm a frightened animal. "My dear lady, I do apologize for our untimely arrival. We mean no harm, I assure you. We are but travelers, seeking refuge from the storm." The woman's gaze flickered to the colonel, and for a moment, I thought I saw a glimmer of amusement in her eyes. But it was quickly extinguished, replaced by a mask of polite curiosity. "Refuge from the storm?" she repeated, her voice husky and confident. "I'm afraid you've come to the wrong place. This house has been...uninhabited for some time." The colonel's face fell, but he rallied quickly, his eyes sparkling with determination. "Ah, but that's precisely why we're here, my dear lady. We're on a mission to...to explore this very house, and uncover its secrets." The woman's smile grew wider, her eyes glinting with a knowing light. "I see," she said, her voice dripping with skepticism. "And what makes you think you'll succeed where others have failed?" The colonel's face set in a determined expression, and I could sense the wheels turning in his mind as he prepared to launch into a lengthy explanation. But before he could speak, a loud creaking sound echoed through the hallway, making us all jump. The woman's head snapped towards the noise, her eyes narrowing. "What was that?" she whispered, her voice barely audible. The colonel's face went pale, and he glanced nervously at me. I shrugged, equally perplexed. And then, as if in answer, the creaking grew louder, more insistent, until it sounded like the very foundations of the house were shifting and groaning. The woman's eyes locked onto mine, and I saw a flicker of fear there, a fear that mirrored my own. What were we dealing with here? And what secrets lay hidden in the depths of this forsaken house?

The house itself was a large and rambling one, with long corridors and many doors, and I had been warned by my employer, Mr. Rucastle, that it was old and prone to creaks and groans, especially at night. I had also been told that I would be sharing the house with Mr. Rucastle's wife and daughter, and that they were both very pleasant and welcoming people. However, as I soon discovered, this was not entirely the case. Mrs. Rucastle was a thin, pinched-faced woman with a perpetual scowl, and her daughter, Alice, was a pale and nervous girl who seemed to be constantly on edge. Despite their chilly demeanor, I did my best to make a good impression and to settle into my new role as governess to Alice, but I couldn't shake the feeling that something was off about the whole situation. As the days passed, I began to notice strange noises and movements around the house, and I started to feel like I was being watched all the time. I tried to brush it off as mere paranoia, but the feeling only grew stronger, until I could hardly sleep at night for thinking about it. And then, one evening, I saw something that made my blood run cold...

es_second_half: a una pequeña dependencia que se encuentra cerca de la puerta de la cocina. Cuando nos acercamos a él, oí el agudo traqueteo de una cadena y el sonido de un gran animal moviéndose.

es_results_raw: a dar un paseo por los alrededores de la casa, y me mostró el jardín y el estanque. Me pareció un lugar muy agradable, pero no pude evitar sentir que había algo extraño en el ambiente. El señor Rucastle me habló de su hija, Violet, y me dijo que era una joven muy inteligente y amable. Sin embargo, cuando la conocí, me pareció un poco reservada y distante. Me pregunté si habría algo que la molestara, pero no quise hacer preguntas. Al día siguiente, mientras estaba en el jardín, vi a Violet hablando con alguien en voz baja. No pude ver a la otra persona, pero parecía que estaban discutiendo algo. Me sentí un poco incómodo y me alejé, pero no pude evitar preguntarme qué estarían hablando. Más tarde, ese mismo día, el señor Rucastle me pidió que lo acompañara a su estudio. Me dijo que quería hablar conmigo sobre algo importante, pero cuando llegamos allí, se quedó callado y no dijo nada. Me sentí un poco confundido y me pregunté qué estaría pasando. De repente, se levantó y se acercó a la ventana. Miró hacia afuera durante un rato y luego se volvió hacia mí. "¿Qué pasa, señor Rucastle?", le pregunté. "Nada, nada", respondió. "Solo estaba pensando en algo". Me sentí un poco aliviado, pero no pude evitar sentir que había algo que no me estaba diciendo.

tr_results_raw: Bayan Akgürgen bana çok kibar davrandı ve bana evin tarihini anlattı. Evin eski sahipleri hakkında konuştu ve bana evin gizli odalarını gösterdi. Odaya girdiğimizde, eski sahiplerin resimlerini gördüm ve Bayan Akgürgen bana onların hikayesini anlattı. O hikaye bana çok ilginç geldi ve evin tarihini daha da merak ettim. Bayan Akgürgen bana evin gizli odalarını daha da gösterdi ve bana evin sırlarını anlattı. O sırlar bana çok şaşırtıcı geldi ve evi daha da sevmeye başladım. Bayan Akgürgen bana evin tarihini ve sırlarını anlatırken, ben de ona evin hikayesini dinlerken çok keyif aldım.
